Daily Musings

Short thought nuggets about the world as they occur to me.

What is the Daily Musings Page?

This page is meant to be an outlet for short thought snippets â€“ no more, no less.

Why have one? Well, the goal, here is to write in free blog form more frequently. The theoretical backbone of daily musings is the following:

I. To produce more with perceived less.

Human nature underestimates what can be done in small increments over a long period of time and overestimates what can be done as a large chunk in a short period of time. A person authoring a book, for example, would likely get way more done writing an hour a day for a year than cramming it in 3 weeks â€“ assuming, of course, that she sticks to that schedule.

Itâ€™s cool to think that in 30 days, Iâ€™ll have 30 awesome thought nuggets up here, especially given that a 5-minute post doesnâ€™t seem all that bad to do everyday ğŸ˜Š

II. To set the bar low in terms of size.

By defining the Daily Musings page as short â€˜thought nuggetsâ€™, I set the bar low in terms of size. This prevents me from procrastinating writing, because writing a tidbit seems far more manageable than writing an entire post.

In other words, itâ€™s way easier for me to meet an expectation of a <500 word thought nugget versus that of a full on 1000+ word post. That comes with less cognitive resistance to posting (i.e. less procrastinating).

Eventually, Iâ€™ll take the date tags off and itâ€™ll just be â€˜Musingsâ€™. But for now, I totally need the extra accountability to continually re-visit and re-post.

III. To make a space for pieces in production.

A lot of the thoughts youâ€™ll see here may end up as full blown posts. Iâ€™ve put them here in the meantime as a holding ground, allowing me to share them in a more raw form until I have the time to scale them into full posts.

Milan | August 1, 2017

Today is my first day in Milan, Italy.

My host took me on a tour of Milan, working our way from the outside in. He had a way of pointing out details Iâ€™d never normally notice â€“ art on columns, the architecture of the city, even pointing out the handle of a store and the way it was designed. Iâ€™m so un-attuned to art.

I think the overall change in how I explored with him versus how I explore by myself is a matter of attentiveness - going slow and embracing all the details not just the most ostentatious ones.

Otherwise, Milan is really great. Traffic wise, people actually stop for pedestrians.

And most interestingly, people of South Asian descent seem to occupy lower waged occupations here in Italy. Iâ€™ve seen a fair number of South Indians busking the streets and in other lower waged occupations. This is very much unlike the U.S., in which South Asians and Asians at large occupy the â€˜model minorityâ€™ role.

One Coin Loophole | July 26, 2017

In her podcast, Happier Gretchen tells a story about coins: Â 

Say you have 10 coins. Are you rich?

Well, no.

What if you add 1 coin? Okay, still no.

What if you add another coin? You keep adding 1 coin by 1 coin. Finally, you have to say that you canâ€™t be rich unless you keep adding 1 coin. One coin by one coin, a person becomes rich and only by the addition of that one coin does she get the growing heap. Â  This is the *One Coin Loophole.

The 1 Coin Loophole is saying on any given day, â€˜well, what does it matter if I skip 1 coin? Doesnâ€™t matter, Iâ€™ll skip it. Which is true, but the irony is that, itâ€™s only 1 coin by 1 coin, small incremental, seemingly non-important action, that gets the desired growing heap. Aka, itâ€™s only one trip to the gym by one trip to the gym that you get the benefits and riches that come from going to the gym.

On Writing | August 7, 2017

Sometimes I have trouble writing. But usually that only happens when I have an unclear sense of what I want to write. Itâ€™s a content problem, not a discipline problem. I think that can be generalized; in other words, writing can be an irritating or drawn-out process, but when you know what to say, when distillation follows distillation, it flows naturally and effortlessly. And when writing happens naturally, I forget everything else and write.

I guess the reason I find blog-making fun, why Iâ€™ve been able to get super into it, is because I love distilling things. Blog-writing (e.g. pretending people out there actually want to read what youâ€™re writing) allows me to engage hours on end in this distillation process and converting nebulous mental schemas into concrete written ones with the satisfaction of knowing other people will be helped by it.

Thoughts on Time Wasters | July 25, 2017

Some interesting tidbits from an article I read by Sara Mauskopf:

Prepare your tasks

I spent time every week figuring out what I needed to accomplish and breaking that work into smaller, bite sized chunks. I had tiny projects that could be completed in a free 15 minutes, larger projects that would require a few hours, and all kinds of stuff in between. This was all waiting for me in priority order.

This way, if I had a few minutes to kill while my husband was waiting for an appointment or a couple hours while my daughter was napping, I didnâ€™t need to waste any of that precious time figuring out what to work on. I got right to work on one of the tasks I had already prepared. This requires upfront planning but doesnâ€™t take very long and it means you only do the planning work once and you have tasks for the whole week. Use Asana or Google Doc for this!â€

Ask for actionable help

People are really bad at being helpful. Even when people ask to help you, they usually donâ€™t follow through with it or do it in a way that is actually helpful. A lot of people would ask me how they could help me with Winnie and Iâ€™d say things like â€œIâ€™d love your feedback on the app!â€ and Iâ€™d hear backâ€¦ nothing.

It turns out â€œgive me feedbackâ€ isnâ€™t actionable enough for most people. Now when someone asks me how they can help I will give them something very specific to do: â€œDownload Winnie at winnie.com/ios and write a review of your favorite playgroundâ€.

When someone completes this task then they naturally also have feedback for me on what worked well or what could be better about the product.

Force yourself to do things imperfectly

To give a very practical example, I have given myself an hour to write this post before Iâ€™m on childcare duty. I can publish the post after that hour or I can spend more time later polishing it and making it perfect. Iâ€™m forcing myself to publish the piece before the hour is up even though it probably has some typos and maybe could be written more concisely.

The extra couple hours I could spend polishing it wonâ€™t make a massive difference in the number of people who read and benefit from this post. Perfectionism is a tough habit to break so you have to set time limits and force yourself to just put things out there even if they arenâ€™t 100% perfect.â€

What would it be like if I focused more on reacting authentically rather than agreeably, rather than fulfilling invisible gender norms?

Needing a Personal Rubric | July 23, 2017

Now that Iâ€™m graduating and a good number of my friends are transitioning into jobs, I canâ€™t help think, whatâ€™s the point? Whatâ€™s the end goal? What means â€œweâ€™ve made itâ€?

Of course, this is the typical student mindset; we want a number or some sort of indicator to quantify our performance.Â 

Â  At 23, Tina Fey was working at the Y.M.C.A, JK Rowling was broke, and Walt Disney had just declared bankruptcy. Similarly, a bunch of other people who weâ€™ll never know of because theyâ€™re still in sub-par conditions, also had the same plight at the same time.

The problem with life is that there isnâ€™t any real performance indicator in the present â€“ only one in retrospect â€“ and what use is that to someone at time t at a fork in a decision tree? Â 

I think in this social-media driven world, itâ€™s incredibly important to have an objective, absolute set of judgments to assess oneself by.Â  Â 

Further, sometimes itâ€™s fun to think about what weâ€™d have our kids do when we raise them â€“ I have this conversation all the time with friends all the time, and itâ€™s so interesting hearing the different way kids are raised.Â  Â 

This, naturally makes me wonder: whatâ€™s the end goal? Why is it important for them to do thing X, Y, or Z?Â  Â 

For this reason, I think it would be insanely useful to draft a rubric of what I perceive to be an accomplished life â€“ at least at this point in my life and a rubric for what a â€˜well raised childâ€™ would look like. Â  Â 

That being said, I donâ€™t know what it means to have a rubric â€“ is that a strength or a shackle? Any kind of rubric Tina Fey would have written at age 23 would have hugely undermined her potential.Â  Â  To be continued as an actual post!

Overcoming Relationship Inertia | July 10, 2017

I have a friendship which maybe isnâ€™t going the best way at the moment and part of me just wants to get super real and try and talk stuff out â€“ to hit some sort of â€˜resetâ€™ button back to the good â€˜ol times. But then, I have to realize that we donâ€™t live in a frictionless world, that indeed friction is a very real force which makes a reset button virtually non-existent.

For example, you can try and say to someone, â€œhey â€“ letâ€™s just reset, do X, and not do Yâ€ and maybe that works on a superficial level, but underneath, there are just too many unresolved feelings and a bit of awkward tension that comes with that â€“ the friction which makes it an unfeasible solution.

The better way, I think, is to just continually be a great person, until slowly they respond in kind.

I think people notice and respond to the integration of behaviors â€“ in other words, actions and behavior repeated over and over again.

Itâ€™s a slower solution but a more tractable one, I think.

FOMO is a very real force | July 22, 2017

There are days when I travel, sometimes Iâ€™ll spend the whole day working on some sort of side project â€“ in other words, somewhat pathetically hunched over my laptop.

And in these moments I tend to feel guilty. Why? Because I feel like Iâ€™m missing out on what [Insert city or country] has to offer. As I type, Iâ€™m currently in Naples, Italy. Now that Iâ€™m here, shouldnâ€™t I be touring Mount Vesuvius or X or Y, instead of sitting on my butt and writing this?

Indeed, the fear of missing out, is a very real force while traveling.Â 

On one hand, it drives me to maximize the use of my time here â€“ which can be a great thing! It pushes me out of my comfort zone and honestly has the upside of potentially happening upon a place/experience/photo that makes it all worth it.

On the other hand, Iâ€™m pretty budget conscious so each paid attempt for an amazing experience/photo has a very real, tangible financial cost. Given that I donâ€™t have that much money, Iâ€™m always tempted to think â€œeh, Iâ€™ll come back when I (hopefully) have more moneyâ€. Of course, the danger in that is that as we grows older, we tend to have money, but no time.Â 

Iâ€™ve also sort of come to terms with and accept doing what I genuinely love doing over the pre-ordained path of action â€” aka the TripAdvisor Top 10 list. Some of my best moments from previous trips, like Harry Potter World, for example, wasnâ€™t going on the Gringottâ€™s ride but rather, as silly as it sounds, really meaningfully connecting with a friend over mozzarella sticks.

So while traveling, Iâ€™ve learned that that the best feelings and the most valued feelings can be simple, not profound, and unplanned, like spending an hour playing with pigeons or retrieving a fallen shirt from a neighborâ€™s balcony (true story . . .).

Of course, thereâ€™s always the opportunity cost of whatever amazing experience you could have had if you had been more thorough, but it helps knowing that I have no idea how great this experience is, so at least emotionally, Iâ€™m not missing out. ğŸ˜›

Interview with first female billionaire + Spanx fouder, Sara Blakely | July 6, 2017

Today I listened to a podcast which undoubtedly is on my all time favorite podcast episodes list â€“ an interview with the Spanx founder, Sara Blakely. Itâ€™s definitely an experiential listen than a pure knowledge-based one so Iâ€™d highly recommend just downloading and getting into it. But below are a couple of the things that really resonated with me.

The notion that ideas are most vulnerable in their infancy.

â€œI kept it [the idea of Spanx] a secret for 1 year. I was very careful right away to keep it to myself because I believe ideas are most vulnerable in their infancy. Itâ€™s instinct to turn to your right or left and tell a friend and when you do that, ego is invited into the mix and then you spend all your time defending the idea and explaining it and not pursuing it. I needed to be at the place where I knew I wouldnâ€™t turn back no matter what I heard. I had invested enough of my time and sweat equity into the idea that I told people and the things I heard were â€œif itâ€™s such a good idea why hasnâ€™t someone done it already?â€ and â€œif itâ€™s a good idea then youâ€™re gonna spend your savings on this and in 6 months, the big guys are gonna knock you out of the waterâ€. And these things were all coming from a place of love but I feel like if I heard all of that at the beginning, Iâ€™d probably still be selling fax machines.â€

Her sheer resolve and willingness to break the rules to get Spanx out there.

[Interviewer] â€œWhen you got into Neiman Marcus - were you like, I made it?â€

[Blakely] â€œAbsolutely not - that is the biggest mistake entrepreneurs make â€“ thatâ€™s when the work begins! I paid friends to go out and buy the product and create a buzz about it.
